title: Trainer-maker Vans faces Hong Kong boycott amid social media backlash over a 'protester shoe'
text:
US skateboard brand Vans is facing a Hong Kong boycott after it removed a protest-inspired shoe from a design competition.

The shoe, which depicted masked protesters, yellow helmets and umbrellas, all evocative of the pro-democracy movement, had garnered thousands of votes and was leading the contest.

But on Saturday, with another week of voting to run, Vans pulled the shoe from its website, sparking a furious response on social media from those who claimed the US brand was looking to protect its market in mainland China.

Vans is the latest company caught in the cross-hairs of the anti-government protests in Hong Kong that have plunged the financial hub into four months of crisis.

The design featured a red bauhinia, the flower on Hong Kong's flag, a yellow umbrella, a nod to the 2014 protests that some refer to as the umbrella revolution, and people in masks on the heel

The design from a Canada-based user named Naomiso was the most popular, according to votes cast online, before it was taken down on Saturday

Many reacted furiously on social media and accused the US sports brand of censorship

A pro-democracy protester throws a Molotov cocktail during a clash With police at a demonstration in Wan Chai district on Sunday

The annual Vans Global Custom Culture competition had received submissions from over 100,000 artists this year, and the shoe-maker invited the public to cast their votes for designs eight days ago.

A design from a Canada-based user named Naomiso was the most popular, according to votes cast online, before it was taken down on Saturday.

It featured a red bauhinia, the flower on Hong Kong's flag, and a yellow umbrella, a nod to the 2014 protests that some refer to as the umbrella revolution.

A group of people wearing helmets, masks and goggles can be seen on the side of the sneaker design.

A search of the username Naomiso on the Custom Culture's website did not yield any result today.

Social media users claimed at least three designs based on the Hong Kong protests had been removed from the competition.

'We have never taken a political position and therefore review designs to ensure they are in line with our company's long-held values of respect and tolerance, as well as with our clearly communicated guidelines for this competition,' Vans said in a Facebook statement on Saturday.

Another shoe design which social media users claimed had also been banned by the skateboarding giant

Others ripped into the US sports brand for its seemingly duplicitous appreciation for 'self-expression'

People on Twitter used the #boycottVans hashtag to spread the message that the US sports brand was not on their side

'Based on the global competitions guidelines, Vans can confirm that a small number of artistic submissions have been removed. This decision was taken to uphold the purpose of Custom Culture,' said Vans, a unit of VF Corp.

Winners will claim $25,000 (£20,300) and have their designs manufactured and sold by the brand.

Vans did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment on Tuesday.
description: The shoe, which depicted masked protesters, yellow helmets and umbrellas, all evocative of the pro-democracy movement, had garnered thousands of votes before it was pulled by the US sports brand.
